data.title: S&P 500 Steadies As Fed Caution And Mixed Earnings Test Rally Strength
data.description:
By Parshwa Turakhiya

​The S&P 500 (SP500) closed near 6,890 on Wednesday, just shy of the 6,900 mark, as investors navigated a volatile session shaped by mixed corporate earnings and cautious commentary from the Federal Reserve. Futures for the index and Nasdaq were steady, while Dow Jones futures slipped on profit-taking in industrials.

The tone across markets reflected hesitation ahead of major earnings releases from Apple and Amazon, and uncertainty over the Fed’s next policy move.

Technical picture shows a wedge formation near resistance

Technically, the S&P 500 remains within a rising channel that has defined the uptrend since May. Price action is now testing the upper boundary near 6,920, a level that has repeatedly capped previous breakout attempts. The 20-day EMA at 6,739 serves as immediate support, followed by the 50-day EMA near 6,622—both aligning with the channel’s midline and marking critical buffers against short-term corrections.

S&P 500 price dynamics (Source: TradingView)

A decisive breakout above 6,920 could propel the index toward the symbolic 7,000 threshold, while a drop below 6,740–6,620 would risk triggering a deeper pullback toward 6,445, where the 100-day EMA and prior demand zone converge. The RSI remains elevated but not extreme, suggesting momentum is intact though vulnerable to fatigue if fresh catalysts fail to emerge.

Earnings volatility and Fed tone shape sentiment

The market’s tone was dominated by post-earnings swings in mega-cap stocks. Microsoft slipped 2% after disclosing a $3.1 billion charge linked to its OpenAI investment, while Meta plunged nearly 9% due to a $15.93 billion expense tied to President Trump’s “One Big Beautiful Bill” Act. In contrast, Alphabet rallied 8% on strong cloud and ad revenue growth, helping offset weakness in other sectors. Eli Lilly added 3.5% after raising full-year guidance, underscoring the continued rotation between growth and defensive names.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks at the post-meeting conference added a layer of caution. While the Fed delivered a 25-basis-point rate cut earlier this week, Powell emphasized that another cut in December was “not a foregone conclusion,” a statement that tempered risk appetite and nudged Treasury yields slightly higher. For equities already priced near record valuations, Powell’s language reinforced that monetary policy may not remain as supportive as markets anticipate.

Macro backdrop offers mild relief

Geopolitical developments provided a modest tailwind. The Trump–Xi summit concluded with a partial trade truce that included a 10% reduction in U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, bringing the overall rate to 47%.

In return, China agreed to curb fentanyl exports and expand purchases of American agricultural goods. While the deal lacked major breakthroughs, it helped ease global risk sentiment by lowering trade-related uncertainty at the margins.

Outlook: Bulls hold control but watch key levels

The S&P 500 continues to trade within a well-defined bullish structure, though near-term gains may be harder to sustain as earnings and Fed policy expectations collide. Immediate resistance sits at 6,920, followed by the 7,000 level, while key supports remain at 6,740 and 6,620.

As previously discussed, the index’s broader trend remains upward, supported by robust earnings in parts of the tech and healthcare sectors. However, with monetary policy tightening expectations in flux and investor positioning stretched, traders should brace for volatility around upcoming earnings reports and macro data releases. The next few sessions will determine whether the S&P 500 can push through to new highs or settle into consolidation before year-end.

This material may contain third-party opinions; none of the data and information on this webpage constitutes investment advice according to our Disclaimer. While we adhere to strict Editorial Integrity, this post may contain references to products from our partners.

data.title: Alphabet: For The First Time In Three Years, My Rating Is Not A Buy (Downgrade)
data.description:
One of the companies I appreciate the most, but I'm not buying now

Over the last three years I have published 9 articles on Alphabet Inc. aka Google (GOOG), and each one presented a Buy/Strong Buy rating. I have always believed in this company’s potential and I invested as much as possible up until few months ago. I still remember when the market was scared about ChatGPT replacing Alphabet’s core business, something that in hindsight proved totally wrong. By the way, now Gemini has 650 million monthly active users.

As a shareholder, I couldn’t be more satisfied by the recent Q3 2025 results, but the price per share is getting a parabolic slope, something that makes me wary.

Of course, as I’ll show you, fundamentals improved a lot and I won’t sell a single share, but is $300 per share a good level to start a position? That is the main question of the article.

Q3 2025 was a terrific quarter

To understand why Q3 2025 was a terrific quarter we just need to look at this slide.

Revenues for the quarter were $87.05 billion, a 14% increase compared to Q3 2024. Last year, revenues improved by 13%, so this means that Alphabet not only is growing, but it is doing so even faster. This is impressive since this company has a market cap over $3 trillion and it grows like a small-medium cap company. At this point, I really don’t know what the limit is, it might even reach $10-20 trillion over the long term.

Google Search & Other, which was supposed to be obsolete a couple of quarters ago, continue to grow by double digits (+15%) and reached $56.56 billions of revenues. In hindsight, we can definitely affirm that ChatGPT hasn't even scratched the Mountain View giant. Actually, Google Search is growing faster and Gemini reached 650 million monthly active users. The market is gradually understanding that AI is not a threat, but an opportunity to get the best out of every business segment of this company, including Google Search:

AI is driving an expansionary moment and transforming how people use Google Search. Our investments in new AI experiences, such as AI Overviews and AI Mode, continued to drive growth in overall queries, including commercial queries, creating more opportunities for monetization. These AI experiences are enhancing how people connect with businesses and shop on Search. We recently added shopping capabilities in AI Mode, which now help people shop conversationally in Search, and we expanded try-on capabilities to more clothing items, now available to anyone in the U.S.

Philipp Schindler, Senior Vice President & Chief Business Officer of Google.

What Philipp Schindler described is basically the reason why Alphabet is among the best companies in the world: it constantly evolves to meet the changing needs of its users and it never gets stuck on what worked in the past. Successful long-term investments require a forward-looking approach, something that is embedded in the Google’s vision.

Now let’s talk about YouTube, of which revenues reached $10.26 billion, a 15% increase year-over-year. In this case as well, the growth rate accelerated, and during the conference call, Philipp Schindler provided interesting insights about the future of this platform.

So in other words, on average, a YouTube Music and Premium subscriber generates a meaningful higher gross profit than they were simply an ad-supported users. Fans come from all over the world. You know this and this engagement through ads and subscription generates YouTube's revenues and funds what I started with, these creators here and this then drives more viewership and engagement and so on. And that's the flywheel.

YouTube initially started with an ad-based business model, but the main goal is making it a subscription-based model. The latter guarantees recurring revenues, regardless the business cycle, and these kinds of businesses tend to be trading at high price multiples. Furthermore, the gross profit on Premium subscribers is way higher than ad-supported users, and this means high profitability. Current paid subscriptions are over 300 million, mainly driven by Google One and YouTube Premium.

The improvement in profitability is already visible in the operating margin, 42.53% (excluding the $3.50 billion EC fine) compared to 40.30% of Q3 2024. Clearly, besides YouTube Premium, much of this margin expansion has been led by the Google Cloud.

Revenues grew by 34%, but operating income has shot up by 85% since it is a highly scalable business. Alphabet will greatly benefit from the operating leverage of this business, and we are still in an early phase. Consider that a mature cloud like AWS can deliver an operating margin of about 40%, almost double than Google Cloud. Currently, Google Cloud makes up less than 10% of total operating income, but its share is bound to get much wider.

Our complete enterprise AI product portfolio is accelerating growth in revenue, operating margins and backlog. In Q3, customer demand strengthened in 3 ways. One, we are signing new customers faster. The number of new GCP customers increased by nearly 34% year-over-year. Two, we are signing larger deals. We have signed more deals over $1 billion through Q3 this year than we did in the previous 2 years combined. Third, we are deepening our relationships. Over 70% of existing Google Cloud customers use our AI products, including Banco BV, Best Buy and FairPrice Group.

Sundar Pichai, CEO & Director.

When you have a business with such a high growth potential and it might reach an operating income of 40-50% over the long term, no wonder why the company increased CapEx once again.

Overall, I am fully satisfied by these Q3 2025 results as Alphabet is becoming a diversified giant. Initially, the whole business relied on Google Search & Other, now we have YouTube Premium and Google Cloud that provide recurring revenues with a high profitability. Plus, they are both growing faster than Google Search.

A matter of valuation

As previously stated, Alphabet remains my #1 position in my portfolio, but its valuation is getting a bit overextended, that’s the reason behind the hold rating. I wouldn’t sell a single share since I plan to hold this great company for the long term (at least 10 years), but at the same time I wouldn’t buy at the current levels.

I think investors had a pretty long-time span (multiple occasions over the last 3 years) to buy some shares, and now it might be too late to jump on the bandwagon. I understand that fundamentals are improving faster than expected, but at this point I think FOMO is starting to set in. Alphabet was traded at $200 just 2 months ago, most of the year even below that threshold. Now everyone wants Alphabet and it seems cheap at $300 per share. But what kind of growth rate the current valuation is pricing in?

Starting from the TTM free cash flow and considering a RRR of 12%, to justify the $300 per share, the company should deliver a 10Y CAGR of 23.50%. So, this means a $607 billion free cash flow by 2035, and a market cap of $12 trillion if we assume a 20x price multiple. Is it possible? Yes. Is it likely? It might be.

I would never bet against Alphabet, but at the same time I would wait a drop before jumping in once again. The expectations are getting pretty high and we know how unpredictable the future is: the current valuation is not pricing in any unexpected event. Of course, I hope I am wrong and my unrealized profits keep spiking up.

data.title: Ameriprise: Cash Sweep Fears Are Overdone
data.description:
Shares of Ameriprise Financial (AMP) have been a poor performer over the past year, losing about 11% of their value. Given how its wealth management unit benefits from rising market levels, the performance this year is particularly disappointing, and it speaks to the fear among investors that Federal Reserve rate cuts will meaningfully reduce cash revenue, a key source of profitability. Q3 results seemingly did little to arrest these concerns, with shares losing 4% in trading Thursday.

I last covered shares in July, rating the stock a “Buy,” and this has been a poor recommendation, with AMP losing 12% since then even as the market has added 8%. With updated financials, now is a good time to revisit AMP to see if performance can improve. I believe fears are overdone.

Markets and cost discipline boost Q3

In the company’s third quarter, Ameriprise Financial actually beat consensus by $0.16, earning $9.92 per share, as revenue grew by 7% to $4.9 billion. Still, this was not enough to send shares higher. There was a -$0.05 impact from its annual review of actuarial performance in its insurance business, which I would not adjust out, meaning earnings were $9.87 per share, in my view. Still, this was up 22% from last year, when its actuarial review was a $0.73 headwind. Excluding this, operating earnings were up a solid 12%.

Aided by a stronger market, assets under management (“AUM”) grew by 8% to $1.7 trillion. Additionally, G&A expenses were down 3% from last year, given ongoing efficiency efforts. Ameriprise also has a strong balance sheet. The company maintains $2.2 billion of excess capital, and it has $2.5 billion of holding company liquidity. As a reminder, it is the holding company that repurchases stock and pays the common dividend. As a result, AMP did $687 million of buybacks in the quarter, and it returned 87% of earnings to shareholders. Thanks to buybacks, its share count is down about 4.3% over the past year. AMP also pays a 1.3% dividend yield.

Cash pressures are manageable

Looking deeper into segment results, wealth management is the core of the business, and revenue grew 9% to $3 billion. Earnings were up a more modest 7% to $881 million, weighed down by lower cash earnings. The company is seeing strong AUM growth, primarily thanks to a rising market, as well as due to organic wins. With higher markets and strong sales activity, revenue per advisor rose 10% to $1.09 million. Advisor compensation was up 11%, maintaining advisory fee and commission growth (advisors are paid a share of their production). G&A was up a comparatively modest 5% to $439 million, as the company generates solid operating leverage.

A key source of profitability for Ameriprise is its cash sweep. Essentially, on cash it custodies in client accounts, it earns net interest revenue, and these earnings are closely tied to the Federal Reserve funds rate. With the Fed having cut interest rates 50bps since September, that will likely pressure cash yields. Still, cash yields are elevated, and with Chairman Jay Powell saying a December rate cut is not a foregone conclusion, I do expect only a moderate cutting cycle. I have been assuming 4-5 cuts over 2025-2026, and this remains my base case. I view this as a manageable headwind, especially given how strong the S&P 500 has been.

Net investment income (net of interest expense) was $383 million, down from $391 million last year. AMP has been able to offset much of the headwind from Fed rate cuts by cutting the amount of interest it pays clients. However, because it shares less than 25% of its interest income, cash sweep balances have faced sustained pressure as investors move into higher-yielding products, like money market funds. This pressure has existed for three years, and while I believe we are approaching the end, balances do not appear to have bottomed out just yet.

Cash sweep balances were down $400 million from last year at $27.1 billion. This was also down by about $300 million sequentially, a slightly disappointing performance, as Q2 balances are often depressed by tax payments. As such, I was hoping to see stabilization this quarter. I do believe we are nearing a bottom here, and going forward, any pressure on cash sweep revenue is more likely to be tied to further Fed rate cuts than balances.

It is also important to note that the wealth management unit is likely to see further benefits from the higher S&P 500. Advisory fees are typically billed in arrears, so Q3 revenue was largely based on where asset levels were on June 30. With the S&P up ~10% over the past few months, that will mechanistically boost revenue in Q4.

While fears around the cash sweep have clearly weighed on the stock, it is important to note that this headwind has been less than 1% of EPS. No doubt, lower balances and lower rates reduce AMP’s earnings, all else equal. Ultimately, though, this pressure is one that is likely to slow earnings growth rather than actually cause a decline in earnings power. With further market tailwinds that have not hit results, this cash headwind is entirely manageable.

Other units are broadly stable

Elsewhere, asset management earnings rose 6% to $260 million, and operating margins were a strong 42%. Revenue was up 3% to $906 million, as fees were stable at 46bps. While a rising market lifts AUM, the company (like many traditional asset managers) has struggled with outflows as investors structurally shift towards lower-fee passive products. Outflows were $3.4 billion, with outflows from both retail and institutional clients. Still, this was a dramatic improvement from the $9 billion seen last quarter. Outflows largely offset market appreciation over the past year, with AUM up just 1% to $714 billion. I expect low-to-mid single-digit AUM growth over the medium term, as market appreciation is partially offset by structural outflows, given the ongoing shift to passive.

Ameriprise also has a comparatively small insurance unit. More than anything, this unit supports its wealth management business, giving its advisors proprietary annuities and insurance products to offer their clients. During the quarter, it earned $200 million; earnings were down about 4% from last year. Sales were strong at $1.4 billion, given ongoing demand for variable annuities in the fairly elevated rate environment. AMP’s insurance unit is extremely well capitalized with a risk-based capital (“RBC”) ratio of 533%, well above the 400+% level I like to see, enabling ongoing capital releases.

Shares are attractive at 11x earnings

Overall, AMP continues to perform well, and while shares are being weighed down by softness in cash revenue, I see this headwind as manageable and factored into valuation. Back in July, I saw the company earning at least $38. I also saw earnings rising to at least $41 next year, while its $2.2 billion of excess capital was worth $25—these factors drove my $600 price target.

I now see EPS of at least $38.25 this year, and I expect EPS of at least $41.50, assuming the S&P remains at or above 6,700. Shares are trading at just 11x forward earnings, without even giving credit for its meaningful excess capital position. As time goes on, and AMP continues to grow EPS, I believe investors will appreciate that cash headwinds are not thesis-undermining, and valuation pressure will dissipate. I view 11x for a fee-based business with a solid balance sheet and strong buybacks as attractive. I would use weakness to "Buy" AMP.

data.title: Rocky Brands Is Still Performing, But Q4 Will Definitely Show Tariff Impacts
data.description:
Rocky Brands, Inc. (RCKY) reported very good Q3 '25 results, with revenues growing MSD and significant gross margin expansion.

The growth is broad-based across all of the company's brands, in particular the two water-related boots (Muck and XTRATUF). The company's gross margin expansion is in a large part related to passing price increases but still recording "cheaper" inventory because of FIFO accounting. This will revert heavily in Q4 '25.

Overall, the name is performing well, but I do not believe it is attractively priced at about 10x earnings, given the outlook for U.S. macro and how growth is related to pricing. I maintain a Hold rating.

Very positive quarter

Rocky's quarter showed positive developments across all brands and across all lines of the income statement.

In terms of revenues, the company continues to post MSD growth, particularly in wholesale at 6% (3/4 of revenues). Revenues were up 7.5% in Q2, and also in Q1, so it has been a very good year.

Last quarter, I was worried this quarter might be worse because of earlier orders from wholesale due to tariffs, but so far, that has not happened.

In terms of brands, the breadth is also improving. For the past year or so, the big performers have been Muck (muck boots) and XTRATUF (neoprene boots), two farming. In this quarter, these brands also performed very well, up double digits in wholesale, mainly from door expansion (they can be sold in farm & ranch, fishing, hardware stores, regular sports shoe stores for XTRATUF, etc.). The company's more classical work boot brands, Rocky and Georgia, were in a worse position, but they are now both growing. The only name to call out is Durango, down, but in this case is where the earlier ordering from Q2 (+10% then) generated an effect.

In terms of gross profits, the company is pulling incredible numbers the whole year, with +390bps in Q1, 300bps in Q2, and now 200bps, all in wholesale. The reason for the gross margin improvement is a better mix (XTRATUF, Muck are better brands in terms of pricing power), lower promos from the recurrent challenges in wholesale post-2022, and, definitely, price increases from the tariffs that are not fully hitting the brands. In this case, the company said the tariff impact on COGS was already a 160bps headwind, meaning prices went up sensibly more.

Operating expenses were probably the area where the company did worse, with OpEx as a percentage of sales growing between 100bps and 150bps (depending on the use of adjusted or not). Still, operating income grew almost 17%, and operating margins grew 70bps.

With lower debt, as the company has been consistently using free cash flow to repay debt, interest also fell by 25% YoY.

Tariffs ahead

Although the results were good, especially surrounding brand development, breadth, and pricing power, I continue to worry about the potential impact of tariffs.

There are some factors to consider.

First, although the company posted 200bps+ gain in gross margins every quarter of 9M25, management reiterated during the call that they expect the company to post 70bps lower gross margins for FY25 than for FY24. Although the aggregate difference is not substantial for the year, the fact that it will be all concentrated in Q4 is relevant. Management also said that the gross margin impact will last at least into 1H25, although sequentially improving. Operating margins will also be lower for the year, despite gains of almost 1pp in 9M25.

Second, if the company's cost headwind is 160bps in this quarter, and has also gained about 200bps of gross margins, then that adds for at least half, if not more, of the growth. It indicates volumes are not growing that much. The company said that its order books look well into Spring 2026 (H1 '26), with no challenges for price, and that sell-through is good, but in these businesses, the channel can easily glut.

Finally, the company's inventory rotation is not that fast, barely above 1x, meaning it takes almost a year to go through inventory. With FIFO accounting (see 10-K under Inventories), that means the company gets to expense the cheapest inventory (from maybe three/four quarters ago) first.

Given that the company has been raising prices to offset higher-priced tariffed inventories, this shows up as a gain in gross margins, even when the business does not have structurally higher gross margins. Part of it also shows up as higher sales, even when no more shoes have been sold.

Rocky is very affected by tariffs, as it has a facility in Suzhou, China, that produces up to 50% of its products in FY24 (see Q4 '24 call). Some brands, like Durango (leather boots), probably have even more exposure (comments in the latest call).

This is without considering the impact on sell-through when consumers face higher prices for many goods in general.

Valuation is still unattractive

The company is expecting to generate about $2.8 in profits per share this year, 10% more than last year (see latest call for guidance). This comes with a decrease in operating margins, but higher sales and, mainly, lower interest expenses.

Compared to this, a current share price of around $29 does not look particularly high. It can be considered fair or even potentially attractive in a more neutral context, especially with many brands growing, the company delevering, and gross margins growing.

However, at least one of those factors (gross margins) is going to revert by year-end. Growth will also be impacted next year as price surcharges are nonrecurring. It is probable that FY26 comes with lower gross margins in aggregate (working through this year's tariffed inventories), with slower growth (LSD maybe). In a more negative consumer-environment scenario, gross and operating margins could decrease significantly.

For this reason, I cannot consider Rocky as attractively priced. It could be considered fair, but not more than that. Therefore, I maintain a Hold rating on the name.

data.title: U.S. Fed Cuts Rates Amid Economic And Data Uncertainty
data.description:
The U.S. Federal Reserve did as expected, cutting its key rate by 25 basis points to a range between 3.75% to 4%. The move comes despite a usually data-dependent Fed having no new statistics to guide its policy decisions because of the government shutdown. Sam Chai, Vice President, Active Fixed Income Portfolio Management at TD Asset Management, speaks with MoneyTalk’s Greg Bonnell about the unique challenges facing the Fed and the road ahead for rates.

Transcript

Greg Bonnell: US Federal Reserve lowered its overnight borrowing rate to a range of 3 and 3/4 to 4%, its second straight interest rate cut. Sam Chai of TD Asset Management here to talk us through the implications.

Sam, great to have you here today.

Sam Chai: Pleasure to be here, Greg.

Greg Bonnell: That first cut, it was called a risk management cut by the Fed. Are they starting to see where this cut in US economy that needs support from lower rates, or are they still just trying to head off any problems?

Sam Chai: I would agree. I think this is a risk management cut by the Fed. And by that I mean the Fed more trying to mitigate potential downside risk, and in particular, trying to risk manage and balance the risks on both sides of the mandate.

So just talk a little bit in more details, on the labor market side, core inflation in recent months haven't been picking up, and cumulative inflation passthrough from the tariff side have actually been slightly lower than the Fed expected. So I would say that while upside inflation risk still remains, it is actually less than feared.

On the other hand, for labor market, while we didn't get the September non-farm payrolls, private sector job data signals that the September labor data likely to be slightly, slightly, continue to be sluggish. And so that downside risk in labor market remains present. So when thinking about that, the upside inflation risk has receded somewhat, while downside labor market risk remains, and that the Fed current policy rate remains restrictive, I think there's a good base for the Fed to make risk management cut today.

Greg Bonnell: When you think about risk management and them not being overly worried about the path forward, I think there was a moment when you and I were watching the press conference with Jerome Powell where he talked about the fact that they're not on a preset course. December is not a done deal. So seems like they're still willing to take it meeting by meeting.

Sam Chai: Mm-hmm. And I don't find it to be particularly surprising because given that we're in this blackout period right now, it's tough for the Fed to pre-commit to a particular path. As we talked about earlier, this is a risk management cut, right? The Fed is not on a preset course to going back to neutral, to cut every meeting to 3%.

And so I still think that the base case or the path of least resistance is for December cut to happen. But of course, that is not a done deal, like Chair Powell himself has said.

Greg Bonnell: So without that official government data going forward, and we don't seem to have a timeline for when they're going to start getting in, how is the Fed navigating? How is the Fed assessing the economy right now?

Sam Chai: So, admittedly, we are in this data fog right now, right? And it's definitely making the Fed's job more challenging. The Fed could be relying on more other type of data, that includes the regional Fed collected data, private sector data, or just their business contacts for qualitative information.

But aside from the federal government data, we still get a variety of other data. For instance, for job market side, we get the JOLTS data. We get state level initial jobless claims data, which, although not published at the federal level, still gives us timely insights into the labor market conditions.

On inflation, we got the latest CPI data for September, but we still receive survey of inflation expectation data, too. And there's also no shortage of GDP nowcast models, which, for instance, the Atlanta Fed publishes. So all this information help to guide our understanding on the macro factor side. But of course, it's making the Fed's job somewhat more challenging.

Greg Bonnell: Now, they also told us today that, as was expected by the market, they will be ending quantitative tightening. I think it was the beginning of December is what they're aiming for there. In the run-up to that, people started talking about quantitative easing. Is it too quick just to go from the end of QT to start talking about QE?

Sam Chai: I think so. I think it is indeed too soon to talk about quantitative easing. I like to think about the Fed changing their policy direction like steering a ship. It's gradual and it's measured.

But taking a step back as to why the Fed is announcing the end of quantitative tightening today, so looking at indicator from money market, from funding market, we have seen that there's a signal that the US economy possibly has transitioned from the abundant reserve regime, which is how the Fed likes to term it, to now an ample reserve regime. So, less abundant.

And the Fed likes to still have ample reserves in the economy to ensure liquidity in the financial market, and also the effective transmission mechanism remain in place for policy rates. So the Fed is not looking to shrink their balance sheet further and reduce the reserve level, and hence why they're looking to end the QT program, as you mentioned, at the beginning of December.

I do think that for us to see quantitative easing, we need to really be in a place where it's very clear the economy needs more support from the policy in a very timely fashion, and that policy rate is likely not having more room to provide that accommodation. Obviously, that's not the case right now because policy rate remains relatively elevated. And so I think we're still quite some distance away from that.

Greg Bonnell: Now one more decision before the end of this year. As we head into 2026, we know that Fed Chair Jerome Powell's term is coming to an end. How much should we be concerned about Fed independence?

Sam Chai: I think that will very much still be a theme going into next year. So Chair Powell's term will be ending next May. Months before that, Trump will be appointing the new Fed Chair. And needless to say, the White House prefers a new Fed Chair who possibly have a much more dovish take on where the monetary policy should be heading versus the current chair.

But to the extent that the market can see that the new Fed Chair decision may have been more politically motivated rather than purely on economic rationales, this could be eroding the market's confidence in the Fed independence, and more importantly, the Fed's ability to anchor inflation over the long term.

The other thing is that earlier next year, we'll have the Supreme Court ruling on Governor Lisa Cook's case. And to the extent that that ruling could be favorable for the White House, that could exacerbate this concern reduced Fed independence.

And just to try to tie it back to the market somewhat, a common way for the market to express this loss of Fed independence theme is by placing a curve steepener bet on the market. In particular, it means that expecting the short end of the interest rate curve to move down on a very dovish Fed. At the same time, the longer end of the interest rate curve could move higher relative to the front end because of the investor being more concerned about long-term inflation and demanding higher term premium. So that will continue to be a theme I think is very interesting to watch next year.

Greg Bonnell: There's a lot there. You broke it down beautifully. How does it all play out for the fixed income markets?

Sam Chai: As we discussed earlier, I do still think that the path of least resistance remains to be a cut in December. Of course, that is not a guarantee. That's not a preset course. But I think the burden of the proof is really on the data to prove that another risk management cut is not warranted.

I think it's also interesting to talk about alternative scenario two, right? I think for the Fed to essentially skip a December cut, what they need to see is two things. One, a refirming of labor market, possibly an increase in pace of monthly job gains, and also a receleration of inflation as well, because the downside risk to labor market is unlikely to dissipate that quickly in a few months of time.

On the other hand, what would be needed for the Fed to deliver a 50 bps cut? Unlikely, but for that, I think the Fed really needs to see a major deterioration in labor market data. And in that scenario, inflation may actually come into second place in considerations. So while I think overall the risk/reward for fixed income security right now is quite balanced, I think it's important to pay attention to that skew in tail scenarios. In particular, pay more attention to labor market data.

Original Post

data.title: Chip-Rip Showdown: AMD Vs. Broadcom
data.description:
Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang is arguably the ringleader of what many feel is a massive "AI bubble." Regardless of if that narrative is right-or-wrong, what we do know is that today (October 29th), Nvidia became the first company in history to reach a market cap of $5 Trillion.

That said, Nvidia isn't the only company building compute engines for the AI market, right? So too are Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Broadcom (AVGO). Today, I'll compare some important investment metrics that investors should consider and choose which of the two "tier-2" companies will likely deliver the best of what investors should care about: total returns. In that regard, and as the chart below shows, over the past year, all three of these companies have significantly best the S&P 500 (SP500) and delivered very strong total returns:

Investment Thesis

The investment thesis for AMD and Broadcom are very similar (although I will note some significant differences, so please read on): both are fab-less semiconductor companies that design AI-specific compute engines. Both companies also aim to tap the massive CapEx spending on AI data-centers that are being driven by the cash-rich hyperscalers (Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and Google (GOOG)) as well as neo-cloud vendors and up-and-coming companies like META (META), Oracle (ORCL), and OpenAI (OPENAI), which are also arguably becoming hyperscalers in their own right.

As you can see from the graphic below from Markets-and-Markets research, what's at stake here is literally $100's of billions of dollars in AI chip's revenue just over the next few years - a market that is expected to grow at a 20%+ CAGR through 2029:

However, these two companies arguably have different strategies. AMD has been focused on competing head-on with Nvidia in the high-end processor market typically used for training large language models, or LLMs, and making these processors available to most any company that wants to buy them. Broadcom, on the other hand, has taken a different path by focusing on developing partnerships with only a handful of high-volume hyperscalers to co-develop application and AI/ML algorithm optimized XPU designs that are sold only to those specific customers and which are typically more often used for inferencing (see Broadcom: The 'Secret Sauce' Behind Its Booming XPU Business). Some investors think I might be splitting hairs here, but these are important distinctions between AMD and Broadcom.

Regardless of the strategy taken, both AMD and Broadcom hope to deliver strong total returns for shareholders by providing more cost-efficient solutions than can be provided by the more expensive GPUs sold by market-leading Nvidia. (As an aside, AMD CEO Lisa Su is a distant cousin of Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang). Both companies should also benefit from the fact that many customers often cannot get the volume of Nvidia GPUs that they would prefer to be allocated to them instead of to their competitors. From that perspective, both AMD & Broadcom are well-positioned to benefit from both of these dynamics.

With that as background, let's compare the two companies on a financial metrics basis.

Basic Investment Metrics Comparisons

The table below compares some of the most important financial and stock metrics (courtesy of Yahoo Finance and Seeking Alpha) that most any investor would consider before investing in either AMD and/or Broadcom:

AMD Broadcom
Market-Cap $418.0 billion $1.79 trillion
TTM P/E 153.3x 96.6x
Forward P/E 65.6x 55.3x
Dividend/Yield N/A $2.36/0.63%
Q2 FY25 Revenue $7.7 billion (+30% YOY) $15.0 billion (+20% YOY)
Q2 Gross Margin 40% 68%
Q2 GAAP EPS $0.54/share $1.03/share
Q2 Net Margin 11.3% 33.1%
Q2 Free-Cash-Flow $1.18 billion (+169% YOY) $6.41 billion (+44% YOY)
Q2 FCF Margin 15.0% 42.7%
Q2 Free-Cash-Flow/Share $0.72/share $1.33/share
ROE (TTM) 4.70% 27.08%
Total Cash $5.87 billion $11.11 billion
Debt-to-Equity 6.51% 166.03%

References: AMD Q2 Report, Broadcom Q2 Report.

As you can see from the chart, Broadcom is a member of the $1 trillion market-cap club and has a market capitalization of 4x+ that of AMD. Broadcom is also trading at a significant valuation discount as compared to AMD on both a TTM and a forward P/E basis.

In addition, and as I have been pointing out in my Seeking Alpha articles, Broadcom is one of the best dividend growth companies in the entire S&P 500 and has been averaging around a 10% dividend increase over the past 10 years:

Broadcom's $0.59/share quarterly dividend doesn't look near as impressive as it did prior to Broadcom's 10:1 stock split last year (otherwise it would be a $5.90/share quarterly payout). And while the current 0.63% yield might not be a consideration to invest in the company today, long-term Broadcom shareholders know that the yield is only "low" because of the stock's excellent price appreciation over the past decade. In addition, note that Broadcom easily covers its annual dividend obligation (and then some ...) with the FCF generated in only two quarters. My point here is that I fully expect Broadcom to announce another 10% (or possibly larger) dividend increase in December.

Regardless, either way you look at it, Broadcom is superior to AMD when it comes to a paying a dividend & dividend growth (AMD currently does not pay a dividend).

Profitability

On a financial basis, perhaps the biggest difference between the two companies is with respect to their margin and free-cash-flow profiles. As you can see in the chart above, in Q2, Broadcom's gross margin was a full 28 percentage points higher than AMD. This gets back to Broadcom CEO Hock Tan's vision and strategy to focus the company only on the best high-margin, high-growth opportunities. As I pointed out in one of my most highly read Seeking Alpha articles, Hock Tan would rather threaten to exit a business than operate one delivering puny margins (see CEO Shakedown: Hock Tan Vs Tim Cook - a Seeking Alpha Editor's Pick).

It may also be indicative of the difficulty AMD may be having when it comes to competing directly with Nvidia (or even Broadcom ...) and the relative discounting it may have to offer in order to close order flow on its processors. On the other hand, with greater adoption of its processors, AMD may turn out to be a margin expansion story, in which case I might change my outlook on the company.

The margin difference, of course, plays a dominant role in terms of the two companies' free-cash-flow profiles. AMD generated $1.18 billion of free cash flow in Q2, which was up nicely on a YOY basis (+169%). From a revenue perspective, that equates to a FCF margin of 15% and $0.72/share. Broadcom generated $6.41 billion of FCF in Q2 (5.4x that of AMD) with a FCF margin of 42.7%. And while Broadcom's FCF margin was almost 3x that of AMD, on a historical basis, a 42.7% FCF margin is actually quite low for Broadcom and has much to do with its relatively recent and large acquisition of VMWare ($69 billion of cash+debt), which closed in November of 2023. Once again, the advantage in financial returns goes to Broadcom, which has an TTM ROE of 27.1% as compared to AMD's ROE of 4.7%.

Balance Sheet

From a balance sheet perspective, the advantage goes to AMD, which has a debt-to-equity ratio of only 6.51% as compared to Broadcom's 166.03%. Indeed, as of Q2, Broadcom, was still carrying $62.8 billion of long-term debt (to go with its $11.1 billion of cash), primarily as a result of the VMWare acquisition. Broadcom has traditionally paid down M&A related debt faster than it has so far done with VMWare, but that is because Broadcom has been more focused on investing quite heavily to take advantage of the tremendous growth opportunities it has with its XPU business with the hyperscalers.

Diversity

While it may be a stretch to call AMD a one-trick pony, it has clearly become a processor-centric company. On the other hand, and as I have been writing for years on Seeking Alpha, Broadcom is arguably the global-leader in high-speed networking and, in Q2, generated 44% of total revenue from its high-margin Infrastructure Software Segment:

As you can see, in Q2, Broadcom generated $6.6 billion in high-margin revenue from its Infrastructure (Enterprise) Software Segment. As compared to AMD, this is important for two different reasons:

  1. Broadcom has a strategic partnership with Nvidia that enables its VMWare Cloud Foundation ("VCF") to offer full-stack support for Nvidia's GPUs. This was very likely a significant headwind for AMD processor adoption amongst potential customers that also want to use VCF. As a result, in August, AMD agreed to collaborate with Broadcom to enable VCF to support its processors as well (almost two years after Broadcom & Nvidia inked its strategic partnership). At this point, Broadcom's VMWare has excellent flexibility because it can support Nvidia GPUs, AMD's processors, and - of course - Broadcom's own hyperscaler XPUs.
  2. Broadcom's Infrastructure Software Segment generates strong annual recurring revenue ("ARR"). This lowers the risk of investing in Broadcom stock, while also increasing the market's valuation of the company as a whole.

Once again: the advantage on software clearly goes to Broadcom.

Meantime, Broadcom's high-speed networking product-line offerings are arguably and consistently the highest-quality, highest-bandwidth, and lowest latency in the industry. Again: this is a huge advantage that Broadcom has over AMD.

I say that because note that Broadcom's XPUs, Infrastructure Software, and high-speed networking business are synergistic. That is, a customer can come to Broadcom and get a fully integrated package of AI data-center solutions across processing, networking, and software. Again: a huge advantage to Broadcom moving forward.

Q3 Earnings

AMD reports its Q3 earnings on November 4th, while Broadcom doesn't report until December 11th. December is very late to report Q3 results, but after years of owning AVGO stock, trust me when I say that it is always worth the wait for AVGO's earnings reports.

Current consensus analysts' estimates per Yahoo Finance are:

  • AMD: Q3 Revenue of $8.75 billion (+28.3% YOY), EPS=$1.17/share.
  • Broadcom: Q3 Revenue of $17.45 billion (+24.2% YOY), EPS=$1.87/share.

As you can see, both companies are expected to continue growing revenue at an impressive pace. On a sequential basis, if AMD hits consensus estimates, it would equate to EPS growth of +116.7% as compared to Q2, while for Broadcom, it would equate to 81.6% EPS growth QoQ. That being the case, in the near-term, it appears that AMD is growing a bit faster from a revenue and EPS perspective, but of course, it is starting from a significantly lower base (i.e. the law of large numbers). Regardless, investors should be keeping a keen eye out for margin: are AMD and Broadcom exhibiting margin expansion? Can AMD close the big gap between it and Broadcom when it comes to net-margin, and it's very different free-cash-flow profile? Time will tell, but I certainly have my doubts, and I am much more confident that Broadcom will, once again, deliver the goods.

Meantime, and while there have been a plethora of much-reported orders, I am still waiting for Broadcom to announce that Apple (AAPL) has placed an order for XPUs, adding another tier-1 hyperscaler to its stable of XPU customers - which already includes Google, META, Byte Dance, and OpenAI. Note that all of these are significant Broadcom high-speed networking customers as well.

OpenAI Deals & CapEx Trends

Earlier this month, AMD and OpenAI inked a multi-year multi-generational strategic partnership to deploy 6 GW of AMD GPUs. The initial phase of the partnership will see 1 GW of AMD Instinct MI450 Series GPUs deployed starting in the 2H 2026.

A week later, Broadcom announced an even larger strategic collaboration with OpenAI that will deploy 10 GW of OpenAI designed XPUs. The multi-year deal will see the two companies working together to deliver combined accelerators and networking systems for large-scale next-generation AI clusters using Broadcom's Ethernet-based scale-up and scale-out technology. Broadcom's deliverables will start in the 2H of 2026 and will consist of racks of AI accelerator & network systems. The deal is expected to complete by the end of 2029. This deal shows one of the inherent advantages Broadcom has over AMD: the ability to package high-speed networking gear along with XPU accelerators in order to own more of the entire AI data-center architecture.

Regardless of which company you like better (AMD or Broadcom), one thing that both of them share with Nvidia is what company makes all these cutting-edge AI processor chips: Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM). That being the case, and considering TSM currently trades at a significant valuation discount to both AMD & Broadcom (TTM P/E=33.9x, forward P/E=29.1x), one could make a good argument that TSMC may be the better investment here.

Speaking of earnings, Google and META just released their Q3 results (see here and here, respectively). As I predicted in my recent Seeking Alpha article "Google: The AI Leader OpenAI Is Still Chasing (But Will Never Catch"), Google delivered a huge beat and its first $100 billion dollar quarter:

  • Google Advertising Revenue: $74.182 billion (+12.7% YOY).
  • Google Cloud Revenue: $15.157 billion (+33.5% YOY).
  • EPS of $2.87/share (+35.4% YOY).
  • Free-cash-flow: $24.461 billion (despite a huge CapEx spend).

Google Search, YouTube, Google subscriptions, and Google Cloud each delivered double-digit growth in Q3 - all driven by Google's Gemini and Infrastructure AI. So much for the popular narrative that OpenAI its ChatGPT chatbot would somehow "kill Google Search." right? Why am I mentioning this here? Because Google is a major XPU customer of Broadcom (GOOG calls them "TPUs") and GOOG announced a further increase in FY25 CapEx from an estimated $85 billion in the Q2 report to a mid-point of $92 billion, or an incremental increase of $7 billion, in the Q3 report released today. And you can bet that a significant chunk of that increase will likely be headed to Broadcom for TPUs and high-speed networking equipment.

Likewise, META - another Broadcom XPU customer - had very strong Q3 results and also increased its FY25 CapEx guidance to a midpoint of $71 billion from the previous midpoint of $69 billion. META also said:

CapEx dollar growth will be notably larger in 2026 than 2025. We also anticipate total expenses will grow at a significantly faster percentage rate than 2025, with growth primarily driven by infrastructure costs.

My point here is that the hyperscalers that are Broadcom XPU and high-speed networking equipment customers are demonstrating strong growth, doing very well, and significantly increasing their CapEx budgets - of which a significantly allocation will quite likely be spent on Broadcom's XPU and high-speed networking products. This bodes very well for Broadcom's near-term upcoming earnings report on December 11th and the company's earnings well into 2026 and beyond.

Summary & Conclusions

Both AMD and Broadcom are clearly operating in the right market at the right time. However, from a financial perspective, Broadcom's margin and free-cash-flow profiles are superior when compared to AMD's. In addition, Broadcom has two businesses (High-speed Networking & Infrastructure Software) in which AMD is a relative no-show. That is a huge advantage to Broadcom when it comes to packaging all three of its offerings (i.e. XPU processor, high-speed networking equipment, and VMWare software) for customers who prefer to deal with one vendor when designing its AI data-center architecture.

When you also consider that Broadcom stock is currently selling at a significant valuation discount to AMD, Broadcom wins this showdown by a mile in my opinion. That being the case, if I owned AMD shares (I do not) I would probably SELL them and BUY more Broadcom (full-disclosure: I do own Broadcom stock).

I'll end with a 5-year total returns chart of Broadcom versus AMD and add the broad market averages as represented by (VOO) and (QQQ) for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq-100, respectively:

As you can see from the graphic, Broadcom has been the clear out-performer of the chosen companies and ETFs. For the reasons stated in this article, I see no reason why the next 5-years won't look very similar to the last 5-years.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Ares Capital: The BDC Sell-Off Was Unhinged, 9.3% Dividend Yield Still Covered
data.description:
Ares Capital's (ARCC) dip over the last few months has been more fear than rational, opening up an opportunity for prospective investors to hold on to a strong dividend yield that's fully covered by net investment income ("NII"). The BDC last declared a quarterly base cash dividend of $0.48 per share, kept unchanged from its prior distribution, and $1.92 per share annualized for a 9.3% dividend yield. The common shares have dipped markedly from their 2025 highs, mirroring a broad BDC sell-off catalyzed by fears that the Fed's dovish pivot to cutting rates would spark widespread dividend cuts. This was overlaid with the dual collapse of First Brands Group and Tricolor to spark systemic credit fears that pulled private credit into its malaise and made selling BDCs into a tradable event. Critically, there was very little exposure to these two junk-rated companies in the highly cyclical automobile sector companies across publicly traded BDCs, with Prospect Capital (PSEC) and small-cap Great Elm Capital (GECC) forming the only two securities in the space with material exposure.

ARCC is the largest BDC by market cap, with a $28.7 billion portfolio at fair value as of the end of the fiscal 2025 third quarter. This drove third-quarter total investment income of $782 million, up 0.9% over its year-ago comp and a beat by $15.43 million on consensus estimates. NII came in at $338 million, around $0.48 per share, down from $361 million, or $0.57 per share, in the year-ago quarter. The $0.09 per share dip in NII per share was primarily driven by a 110 basis point dip in the weighted average yield on total investments at amortized cost from 10.7% to 9.6% as of the end of the third quarter. The direction of this is down, with 50 basis points of rate cuts since September, and a likelihood of another 25 basis points rate cut at the upcoming December 10 rate-setting meeting.

Originations And Credit Quality

Hence, the focus moves to the cadence of originations and credit quality to determine just how effective ARCC will be in navigating an environment of failing rates with a 71% floating rate portfolio as of the end of the third quarter. This is lower than peers, and is somewhat of a plus in an environment where yields are being pulled down by the Fed. It comes as ARCC ramps up gross commitments to maintain investment portfolio growth. Gross commitments were $3.92 billion during the third quarter, up a material 53% sequentially and roughly flat versus gross commitments a year ago. It was set against exits of $2.63 billion for positive net commitments of $1.3 billion during the third quarter. ARCC is aligned with the BDC camp that has sped up originations to counter falling rates. This includes Hercules Capital (HTGC) and Trinity Capital (TRIN).

The risk would be just how much credit quality could change. ARCC had 1% of its portfolio at fair value on non-accrual status as of the end of the third quarter. This was down 20 basis points sequentially but up from 0.6% a year ago. This is still well within a prudent historical range, which renders the selling off seen recently as relatively unhinged. This sell-off would drive the commons to the April "Liberation Day" tariff lows. However, it's becoming increasingly clear that the dual failures were isolated idiosyncratic risk events, and their extrapolation to the broader private credit space was unnecessary.

Conclusion

ARCC's investment backlog at the end of the third quarter was $3 billion, with the BDC now clearly pushing for a larger allocation to first lien credit, as this formed 85% of its backlog. NII per share is currently covering its dividend by 100%, an exact ratio that leaves very little room for NII to dip in future quarters. This coverage came as its net asset value per share of $20.01 grew by $0.12 versus its year-ago comp. ARCC is a hold at its current level.

data.title: High Valuation, Weak Growth: Starbucks Is In Trouble
data.description:
Among the many companies reporting quarterly earnings these days is also the third-biggest restaurant chain by market capitalization – Starbucks Corporation (SBUX). Aside from McDonald’s Corporation (MCD), DoorDash, Inc. (DASH) now has a market capitalization ahead of Starbucks. In my last article about Starbucks, published at the beginning of April 2025, I wrote in my conclusion:

In my opinion, Starbucks can still be seen as fairly valued right now. And while I would still call Starbucks a great long-term investment, I see downside risk in the short term. Depending on the question if the United States will enter a recession and how steep the recession will be, a valuation multiple of 30 or higher might not be justified and Starbucks could decline rather steep (especially as earnings per share and free cash flow will also contract in such a scenario). Looking at the Great Financial Crisis is demonstrating how steep Starbucks could fall.

But over the long run, Starbucks is probably fairly valued and can be seen as a solid investment at this point. It is not a bargain, but probably also not overvalued.“

Back then, I was already cautious and pointed out that we are still dealing with a great business and a potential long-term investment. But I also made clear we should not ignore the short-term risks. At this point, I would not only classify the risks as rather short-to-mid-term but also see the risks as the bigger issue.

Since my last article was published, Starbucks has declined about 14% (this was written before market open) and clearly underperformed the overall market and a declining stock price is in most cases shifting the risk-reward ratio towards a more bullish opinion. However, due to the continuous struggles of Starbucks (exemplified by the underwhelming quarterly results), the still high valuation multiples the stock is trading for and the risks looming on the horizon, I would be even more cautious about Starbucks as an investment. In the following article, I will explain why I actually sold my Starbucks position a few months ago and why I see the stock being a “Hold” at best.

Valuation Multiples

The biggest problem for Starbucks investors is still the high valuation multiples. At the time of writing, Starbucks is still trading for 36.4 times earnings per share and 42.5 times free cash flow. Without much doubt, these are extremely high valuation multiples.

In the case of Starbucks, we could argue that the stock always traded for high valuation multiples and therefore current valuation multiples seem in line with previous numbers. Hence, we can argue that Starbucks might be fairly valued and neither under- nor overvalued. However, valuation multiples can’t be justified by looking only at previous data or comparing a company to its industry peers. High valuation multiples can only be justified by high expected growth rates in the years to come.

Quarterly Results

To answer the question of whether Starbucks deserves the high valuation multiples we can start by looking at the last quarter's results. While Starbucks did beat revenue estimates by about $250 million, it did miss earnings per share expectations. Aside from beating expectations, total net revenue increased from $9,074 million in Q4/24 to $9,569 million in Q4/25 – resulting in 5.5% year-over-year growth for the top line.

While revenue increased in the mid-single digits, operating income declined steeply (78.7% year-over-year) from $1,306.9 million in the same quarter last year to $278.2 million in this quarter. Diluted net earnings per share also declined from $0.80 in Q4/24 to $0.12 in Q4/25 – resulting in 85% year-over-year decline.

The full-year results are actually not much better, only when looking at adjusted diluted earnings per share, the decline less steep. Of course, we find some positive news in the last earnings report like global comparable store sales increased 1%, making this the first positive quarter in seven quarters. In the United States, comparable store sales were flat year-over-year with average ticket up 1% (reflecting fewer discount-driven offers in the current year).

Among the three segments, it was especially Channel Development that grew with a high pace (16.6% year-over-year growth), but the segment is only responsible for about 5.5% of total revenue and the company was unable to transfer high revenue growth for the segment into bottom-line growth as operating income increased only 0.2% year-over-year to $265.2 million.

Situation in China Improving

One of the most important markets for Starbucks is still Mainland China as it offers huge growth potential for the business (in comparison to the United States, a market that is probably saturated already). And in the last few years because of China’s economy struggling, Starbucks also struggled. However, the situation in China is improving and net revenue increased 6.1% year-over-year from $783.7 million in Q4/24 to $831.6 million in Q4/25.

The store count continues to increase in China with Starbucks opening 415 stores during the last twelve months (net store openings) and having 8,011 stores in China at the end of Q4/25. Comparable store sales increased 2% with average ticket declining 7% year-over-year and average transactions increasing 9% year-over-year.

I, personally, am rather optimistic that the Chinese economy will continue to improve again, however the data must still be described as mixed. GDP is growing, and retail sales are also growing, but for China, these are rather low growth rates. Consumer confidence is also improving in the last few quarters but compared to the years before 2022 it is still extremely low. What makes me rather optimistic is the CSI 300 index, which might have found its bottom and is marching higher in the last few months. And the stock market usually being a leading indicator, this might be a slightly bullish sign.

United States: Huge Question Marks

China is certainly an important market and might contribute to growth for Starbucks, but we should also not ignore that China still generates only about 8.5% of total sales for Starbucks and the most important market is without doubt the United States (responsible for two-thirds of total revenue).

In my last article I already talked about the risk of the United States entering a recession. And despite the stock market making new all-time highs and sentiment being extremely bullish, I see the picture slowly worsening. Of course, the following selection of indicators is certainly not perfect and is biased in some way, but aside from the treasury yield (visualized by the T10Y3M and T10Y2Y), which inverted and “re-inverted” again and is a strong sign for a recession, there are other early warning indicators. One metric we can look at might be the Consumer Sentiment.

The last reported consumer sentiment was 55.1 and compared to 70.1 one year ago, the consumer sentiment declined 21.4% year-over-year. One month ago, the consumer sentiment was 58.2 and it is also very close to its all-time low, which is not a good sign.

Additionally, we can look at the housing permits. The last reported housing permits were 1.330 million and compared to 1.476 million one year ago, the housing permits declined 9.89% year-over-year. One month ago, the housing permits were 1.362 million. And although we don’t see a similar steep decline as in previous recessions so far, we have to acknowledge the decline happening in the last few quarters.

And initial claims for unemployment insurance have been slightly increasing (but still at a low level). However, the economy is hardly adding jobs anymore and this is not a good sign. However, other leading indicators like the Sahm Rule are not indicating a recession so far.

And this is making me very cautious about Starbucks. On the other hand, the company can grow its delivery business in the United States by 30% year-over-year in the fourth quarter and is surpassing $1 billion in sales for the full year. Additionally, Starbucks is optimistic its “Back to Starbucks” strategy is working and CEO Brian Niccol stated during the last earnings call:

A year ago, we launched our Back to Starbucks strategy to get us back to the exceptional craft, connection and welcoming coffee houses that define the Starbucks Experience and set us apart. Since then, we've been focused on executing our plan and accelerating it where we've seen opportunity. We took the significant step of scaling several key pieces of work during the quarter, and it's clear from our results that our plan is working, and our turnaround is taking hold.

Part of this strategy is assessing stores and closing unprofitable stores. During the last earnings call, CFO Catherine Smith stated:

This included the completion of our assessment of our coffee house portfolio and identified closures as well as a simplification of our broader support organization to one that is streamlined and more closely aligned to our future growth priorities. Let me walk through some of the impacts to our financials. In the fourth quarter, we had 107 net store closures globally as part of the restructuring we announced in September. These coffee houses were deemed unable to meet our standards for customer experience even through a potential uplift or for profitability.

Aside from closing stores, Starbucks is also uplifting some of its stores and has a new coffee house prototype and has completed nearly 70 uplifts so far and is planning about 1,000 uplifted stores until the end of fiscal 2026.

Weakening Moat

Another question is whether Starbucks still has a wide economic moat and therefore a strategic advantage that will lead to above-average growth in the years to come. Starbucks’ economic moat is built heavily around its brand name, which enables the company to charge premium prices to its customers. However, in the list of top 100 global brands (by Interbrand), Starbucks is obviously not among the top 100 anymore. In previous years, Starbucks was usually listed somewhere around spot 50 and falling out of that list would indicate a steep decline in brand value.

Another red flag is the declining return on invested capital in the last five years. It should be noted that Starbucks is still reporting high ROIC metrics (in the last twelve months it was 14.2%), but the company cannot come close to the numbers it was reporting before 2020.

Hand-in-hand with lower return on invested capital, Starbucks must report constantly declining margins, which is also not a good sign. I used a chart with data since 2010 to demonstrate how the company was able to improve its margins until 2017 but was struggling in consecutive years. Even when excluding the quarters around 2020 when the pandemic and resulting stay-at-home orders hit Starbucks hard, we see a downtrend that is accelerating in the last few quarters.

The picture of a struggling business is completed by revenue growth rates slowing down in the last few years. Revenue growth for the most recent quarter is not included in the data and despite slight improvements we must ignore these short-term fluctuations as the bigger trend is showing growth rates are slowing down.

In the end, lower revenue growth and declining margins are also resulting in a declining bottom line and earnings per share as well as free cash flow fluctuating rather heavily.

Intrinsic Value Calculation

I argued in the section above that Starbucks is trading for extremely high valuation multiples and argued that this is a problem. However, we must be a little cautious and not only look at simple valuation multiples as they are sometimes misleading. Valuation multiples are using the results of the last four quarters, which can be an outlier leading to much higher or much lower valuation multiples.

Instead, we use a discounted cash flow calculation to determine an intrinsic value for Starbucks. As always, I calculate with a discount rate of 10% (the annual return I like to achieve at least from an investment) and 1.141 billion diluted shares outstanding. Now it is getting more difficult as we have to make assumptions for the years to come.

In an optimistic scenario we can assume that Starbucks will be able to grow with a high pace in line with analysts estimates, which see Starbucks growing at least in the low to mid-teens in the years to come. As basis we can take the free cash flow of the last four quarters, which was $2.442 billion and when assuming Starbucks will grow between 12% and 13% in the next ten years followed by 6% growth until perpetuity, the stock is fairly valued right now.

It is difficult to assess how realistic these assumptions are. Over the last ten years, earnings per share actually declined, but when taking a different year, the picture is completely different and earnings per share are growing in the high single digits or even double digits due to the heavy fluctuations (see section above). Revenue grew with a CAGR of 6.42% in the last five years and a CAGR of 8.20% in the last ten years. Combining these revenue growth rates with improving margins, double-digit growth rates seem possible again. However, when assuming that Starbucks might only be able to grow in the mid-to-high single digits, we get an intrinsic value of $50 to $60, and the stock is still overvalued.

Conclusion

The problem for Starbucks can be summed up quite simply. Even when estimating that Starbucks’ situation can improve again and the company might grow with a higher pace, the stock is still trading for extremely high valuation multiples and high growth expectations are already reflected in the stock price. There is little upside for investors here: If Starbucks can actually improve its business again, it is good for investors and is making the stock fairly valued. If the situation for Starbucks is not improving, the stock is overvalued and might decline in the coming months and quarters. Maybe investors won’t lose any money, but there is not much upside potential at this point.

The combination of declining margins, low revenue growth rates, the risk of the United States (and many other countries around the world) entering a recession and the high valuation multiples for Starbucks makes me extremely cautious right now and the stock is still a “Hold” at best.

data.title: TSMC Stock And The AI Bubble: 40%+ AI Accelerator Growth Fuels Valuation Debate
data.description:
Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) recently announced fiscal Q3 earnings, stating its longer-term AI revenue outlook is stronger than anticipated. The company reported record Q3 revenue of $33.1 billion, which was up by a solid 40.8% year-over-year and 10.1% sequentially.

Over the last few months, the stock has surged as it’s up 50% since early June. At the time, we covered the stock in an article covering AI growth and geopolitical risk, providing a scenario that could take the stock toward the $300s:

If we see the next drop take the form of a 3-wave drop that holds over $146, then we could be setting up for a rally toward the $300s.”

At time of writing, the stock was at $203 and touched $304 on Oct. 15.

For Taiwan Semiconductor, the outlook is two-fold. On one hand, TSMC is deepening its moat with advanced nodes, such as N2 and A16. The company already powers tens of trillions in market cap on the stock market when you consider Apple (AAPL), Nvidia (NVDA), Broadcom (AVGO), Amazon (AMZN), AMD (AMD), and Google (GOOG) (GOOGL) are customers of TSMC. Essentially, all mega-cap stocks have an AI strategy spanning merchant GPUs and custom silicon, and of course, software—yet the common denominator to these strategies is they all funnel into TSMC.

Yet, on the other hand, many pundits have been asking, are we in an AI bubble? While AI leaders, related suppliers, and strong R&D teams march onward with exceptional earnings reports, ongoing deal announcements and provide strong commentary that AI demand greatly outstrips supply, investors are left wondering what the true value is for the outsized growth. They say a picture is worth a thousand words, and TSMC’s valuation chart certainly fits that description:

Although no risk management strategy will be entirely error-free, we have a plan to handle the tech sector’s inevitable volatility, something we provide to stock newsletter subscribers. We seek to maximize the upside while protecting to the downside.

Below, we discuss the key items to track to see whether TSMC’s moat is intact—even as Intel (INTC) increasingly becomes a US darling with $11B in funding—plus not-to-miss highlights from the most recent earnings report. Last, we won’t leave you hanging with a note on how we managed our position after the strong run-up in June.

TSMC Reports Record Q3 Revenue Growth of 40.8% on Surging AI Chip Demand

  • TSMC revenue beat management guidance by 2.2%, primarily due to robust AI-related demand.
  • Riding strong AI chip demand, TSMC once again boosts its full-year revenue growth guidance by 5 percentage points.

TSMC reported a record Q3 revenue of $33.1 billion, up 40.8% YoY and 10.1% sequentially. The growth was primarily driven by strong demand for its leading process technologies (including 3nm, 5nm, and 7nm process nodes) due to the continuing demand for AI and high-performance computing chips.

TSMC guided Q4 revenue of $32.2 billion to $33.4 billion, representing YoY growth of 22% and down (-0.9%) sequentially. Although management emphasizes strong AI-related demand, the guide shows a break in strong QoQ HPC revenue growth (more on this below).

TSMC boosted full-year revenue guidance by 5 percentage points for the second consecutive quarter to mid-30% on continued strong AI demand. This is up from the 30% growth provided in Q2.

Management sounded very optimistic during the Q3 earnings call about long-term AI growth opportunities. As discussed below, AI momentum is stronger than expected. The growing adoption of AI consumer models is driving strong demand for AI chips. Similarly, enterprise AI demand is strong, and the rising sovereign AI opportunity will become another strong growth driver.

TSMC: AI Accelerator Growth to Hit Mid-40% CAGR by 2029

Management commentary suggested the chipmaker’s AI outlook through 2029 may be revised higher than the previously guided mid-40% CAGR, though TSMC declined to provide an updated figure, opting to hold off until early 2026:

AI demand actually continues to be very strong, (it's) stronger than we thought three months ago, OK? So in today's situation, we have talked to customers and then we talk to customers' customer.

So the CAGR we previously we announced is about mid-40s. It's (still) a little bit better than that. We will update you probably in beginning of next year so we have a more clear picture. Today, the (numbers) are insane.”

TSMC Reports Softer HPC Growth After Historic Q2 Gains

TSMC reported a softer QoQ increase in HPC revenue in Q3 after the chipmaker posted its largest sequential growth in Q2 at nearly $3 billion. Q3 saw sequential growth of just over ~$800 million in USD terms, or ~5% QoQ, versus over 20% QoQ growth seen in Q2. However, Q3’s USD-visible growth continued to be inflated by forex, as HPC revenue in NTD was approximately flat QoQ at ~NT$564 billion, versus over 13% growth in Q2.

However, looking closer, HPC also saw its percentage of total revenue decline three points from Q2 to Q3, from 60% of total revenue to 57%. Meanwhile, smartphone revenue came in quite strong, gaining three points in total revenue to 30% share as revenue surged nearly 23% QoQ to $9.9 billion.

The softness in HPC revenue may stem from the upcoming platform shift to Nvidia’s Rubin architecture, which relies on a customized 3nm node, N3P, whereas Blackwell relies on TSMC’s N4P process, a customized 5nm node. As you can see in the chart below, TSMC reported a decline in HPC QoQ and YoY revenue at the time that Nvidia’s previous generation Hopper began to ship around Q1 2023. The decline persisted for a few quarters before TSMC resumed very strong QoQ growth in early 2024.

Nvidia’s upcoming Rubin generation is slated to be released in the second half of 2026, as six variations entered trial production in August. According to CFO Collette Kress:

The chips of the Rubin platform are in the fab. The Vera CPU, Rubin GPU, CX9 Super NIC, NVLink 144 scale-up switch, Spectrum X scale-out and scale-across switch, and the silicon photonics processor (for co-packages optics). Rubin remains on schedule for volume production next year.”

According to Tom’s Hardware, Nvidia and its partners have “successfully created the photomasks and put Nvidia's Rubin GPU, Vera CPU, and various scale-up and scale-out switching ASICs to production.” The article states that Nvidia is now awaiting them to verify performance, power, and other criteria.

Although TSMC serves many high-profile customers in its HPC segment, such as AMD, Broadcom, and Intel, it goes without saying that Nvidia is the heavyweight driving the larger swings in this segment, as Nvidia has 10X AI revenue in the $200B range compared to second-place Broadcom in the $20B-ish range. As Tom’s Hardware estimates, it could take 9-12 months or longer for Rubin to enter production.

Meanwhile, TSMC will likely report a lull in the HPC segment between the Blackwell and Rubin generations, as Nvidia represents the lion’s share of this segment.

TSMC’s Q3 EPS Surges 50.5% Year-over-Year, Beating Estimates by Over 12%

As much as TSMC is a top-line story, it's equally a bottom-line story. The company’s EPS grew by 50.5% YoY to $2.92, beating estimates by an impressive 12.3% with the strongest beat in the last two years.

Analysts expect Q4 EPS to grow 26.8% YoY to $2.84 in Q4 and grow 25.5% in Q1. Looking forward, they expect EPS to grow 19.8% YoY to 12.34 in 2026 and 24.6% YoY to $15.48 in 2027. Due to TSMC’s economies of scale, the margin dilution from overseas fab expansion is expected to be 1%-2% in 2025, lower than their initial estimate of 2% to 3%.

TSMC Stock Trades at Very High Valuation

Despite TSMC’s strong bottom-line growth, the stock trades at one of the highest bottom-line valuations since the AI boom began. As visible below, even the strong fiscal Q3 EPS beat of 12.3 points and strong forward EPS guide are not making a dent in the stretched valuation.

The AI trade has been particularly hard to nail on valuations. For example, we see some stocks, such as Palantir (PLTR), trading as high as 100 forward P/S, there are long-standing stocks like Broadcom trading higher than they ever have in their history, and it seems there are new deals being announced every day followed by 20%-plus pops.

Regarding TSM, it’s up 290% since early 2023, while the Nasdaq is up 127% and market favorites like Apple are up 98%. There's no denying that TSMC has been a strong performer, as it’s the common denominator across the AI accelerator supply chain.

Below we look at the following to determine how to approach the combination of a strong AI stock with a high valuation:

  • The top reason that TSMC has seen strong price action and what must happen for the strong price action to continue.
  • How to weigh the United States providing more funding to Intel (to date) compared to TSMC.
  • A new trade setup for TSM now that our original trade plan has played out as described last June.

TSMC Strengthens Pricing Power as GPUs Transition to Advanced 3nm and 2nm Nodes

TSMC’s impressive price performance reflects many factors, but at its core, it comes down to the company’s unmatched pricing power in the AI ecosystem. As we had discussed earlier, the chipmaker is the common denominator to essentially all mega-cap stocks’ AI strategies, and the company is deepening its moat with more advanced nodes, such as N2 and A16.

As chips progress to these more advanced nodes, such as Nvidia’s Rubin moving to 3nm and AMD now building CPUs on 2nm, TSMC stands to benefit from increased pricing power. This is because wafers at these new and upcoming nodes carry significant premiums versus the prior node, accounting for substantial increases in performance or power efficiency.

Pricing for TSMC’s 3nm node was originally pegged by analysts at ~$18,000 per wafer at the start of 2025, before rising just over 10% to $20,000 by September, per reports. This would give the 2nm node a ~50% premium with its reported pricing at $30,000 per wafer.

Now, reports claim that supply chain sources suggest 3nm pricing is closer to $25,000 to $27,000 per wafer, a 50% uplift from the start of the year. This is important for TSMC, as this process underpins Nvidia’s Rubin, which is expected to see shipments of ~5.7 million units next year, per JPMorgan.
